name: fatty acid production, from coconut oil | fatty acid | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/16228/documentation

The functional unit is 1 kg of fatty acids - based on the oil from coco nuts. Coconut fatty acids and their fractions can either be used directly or converted to other derivates, covering a broad range of applications in the oleochemical industry. The largest part of coconut fatty acids goes into the manufacture of toilet soap, where its lauric content provides the required lathering properties (Gervajio, 2005).;Reference:  Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.;For more information on the model please refer to the dedicate ecoinvent report, access it in the Report section of ecoQuery (http://www.ecoinvent.org/login-databases.html);[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:; - fatty acid production, from vegetable oil, GLO, 1995 - 1995 (21eba3e6-0c60-4feb-b588-f51f2ad48514)]

The activity starts when the raw materials enter the process.

Materials entering the process are included as well as energy uses, infrastructure and emissions.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The activity is based on literature data from 2005, 2013 and 2015.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inputs to the process are calculated based on stoichiometry and literature data, they are therefore considered to be valid for the chosen geography.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Coconut oil is split into its corresponding fatty acids and glycerine. In the chemical reaction triglyceride reacts with water to fatty acid and glycerine, for example:;RCOOCH2 + 3 H2O → RCOOH + CH2OH;Gervajio (2005) describes four possible technologies applied for the fat-splitting process. Here we model the continuous process (also known as Colgate-Emery Process), which is the most efficient of the current technologies (up to 99%). A high degree of splitting is achieved through a countercurrent flow of oil and water under 250-260 degree C. A catalyst is not needed, however, can be employed.;In a second stage after splitting, the fatty acids are distilled to remove the high and low boiling impurities. This happens in a distillation tower under vacuum and about 200 degrees C. The distilled fatty acid is free of major impurities and is of close to water white color. IPS Engineers (2013) mention a process efficiency of 85%-95%, therefore we apply the average of 90%.;In a third step, fractionation, specific components, such as C12 for lauric acid/dodecanol production, are separated. For a lack of better information, we approximate electricity and steam use of fractionation with data reported for vegetable oil processing in India (TERI, 2013).;Reference:  Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.;IPS Engineering. 2013. Oleochemicals - Processing Plant. Retrieved online from http://www.ips-engineering.it/Doc/Oleochemicals.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017;The Energy and Resource Institute (TERI). 2013. Widening the coverage of PAT Scheme, Sectoral Manual – Vegetable oil industry, p. 15. Retrieved online from http://shaktifoundation.in/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/widening-of-pat-sectors-vegetable-refineries.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017;For more information on the model please refer to the dedicate ecoinvent report, access it in the Report section of ecoQuery (http://www.ecoinvent.org/login-databases.html)

exchanges.description:
Coconut fatty acids and their fractions can either be used directly or converted to other derivates, covering a broad range of applications in the oleochemical industry. The largest part of coconut fatty acids goes into the manufacture of toilet soap, where its lauric content provides the required lathering properties (Gervajio, 2005).

Reference:  Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.

flow.name: fatty acid
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

exchanges.description:
This is reported as 3m3 for the splitting and 15m3 for the distillation. The value is scaled to the amount of reference product assuming an efficiency of 0.99 (Gervajio, 2005) for splitting and 0.90 for distillation (IPS Engineering, 2013).
Sources: 
Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.
IPS Engineering. 2013. Oleochemicals - Processing Plant. Retrieved online from http://www.ips-engineering.it/Doc/Oleochemicals.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017

flow.name: Water, cooling, unspecified natural origin
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/in water

exchanges.description:
This is reported as 10kWh in the fat splitting of 1 tonne of crude coconut oil, and 5 kWh in the subsequent distillation of 1 tonne of fatty acid from coconut oil (Gervajio, 2005). The electricty consumption for fractionation is approximated using the average (12.5 kWh/tonne) of the range 10-15 kWh/tonne of oil, reported for fractionation of vegetable oil in indian plants with a daily capacity of 100 tonnes (TERI, 2013). The summed value is scaled to the amount of reference product using an efficiency of 0.99 (Gervajio, 2005) for the splitting, 0.90 (OPS Engineering, 2014) for the distillation and an assumed efficiency of 0.95 for the fractionation (no information available). 
Sources: 
Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.
IPS Engineering. 2013. Oleochemicals - Processing Plant. Retrieved online from http://www.ips-engineering.it/Doc/Oleochemicals.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017
The Energy and Resource Institute (TERI). 2013. Widening the coverage of PAT Scheme, Sectoral Manual – Vegetable oil industry, p. 15. Retrieved online from http://shaktifoundation.in/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/widening-of-pat-sectors-vegetable-refineries.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The values are calculated based on the water input. The share of water to air and water to water are taken from industry data. The values are a 5-year average of data (2011 - 2015) published by the Gendorf factory (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de), (Gendorf, 2015, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de), (Gendorf, 2014, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de). The Gendorf factory is based in Germany, it produces a wide range of chemical substances. The factory produced 1657400 tonnes of chemical substances in the year 2015 (Gendorf, 2016, Umwelterklärung, www.gendorf.de) and 740000 tonnes of intermediate products.

exchanges.description:
This is reported as 190kg of steam (6000kPa) used in the fat splitting process of 1 tonne of crude coconut oil, and 370kg (5000kPa) and 150kg (300-1000kPa) of steam for the distillation of 1 tonne crude fatty acid (Gervajio, 2005). Gervajio (2005) further reports 120kg of export steam from the destillation process. For a lack of better information we assume this export steam to be used in the seubsequent process of fractionation with a requirement of 150kg steam per tonne of input (approximated with values from vegetable oil fractionation in india from TERI (2013)). Therefore we add only the remaining difference of 30kg steam for fractionation. These were converted to MJ using the specific steam enthalpy for the respective steam parameters added up and scaled to 1 kg of reference product, assuming an efficiency of 0.99 (Gervajio, 2005) for the splitting and, 0.90 for the distillation (IPS Engineering, 2013) and 0.95 (assumption) for the fractionation.
Sources: 
Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.
IPS Engineering. 2013. Oleochemicals - Processing Plant. Retrieved online from http://www.ips-engineering.it/Doc/Oleochemicals.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017

flow.name: heat, from steam, in chemical industry
flow.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

defaultProvider.name: market for heat, from steam, in chemical industry | heat, from steam, in chemical industry | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: D:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/35:Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply/353:Steam and air conditioning supply/3530:Steam and air conditioning supply

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical.

References:
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH.
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.

exchanges.description:
This is reported as 10kWh in the fat splitting of 1 tonne of crude coconut oil, and 5 kWh in the subsequent distillation of 1 tonne of fatty acid from coconut oil (Gervajio, 2005). The electricty consumption for fractionation is approximated using the average (12.5 kWh/tonne) of the range 10-15 kWh/tonne of oil, reported for fractionation of vegetable oil in indian plants with a daily capacity of 100 tonnes (TERI, 2013). The summed value is scaled to the amount of reference product using an efficiency of 0.99 (Gervajio, 2005) for the splitting, 0.90 (OPS Engineering, 2014) for the distillation and an assumed efficiency of 0.95 for the fractionation (no information available). 
Sources: 
Gervajio, Gregorio C.. 2005. Fatty Acids and Derivates from Conconut Oil, Bailey's Industrial Oil and Fat Products, Sixth Edition, Six Volume Set. Edited by Freidoon Shahidi. John wiley & Sons, Inc.
IPS Engineering. 2013. Oleochemicals - Processing Plant. Retrieved online from http://www.ips-engineering.it/Doc/Oleochemicals.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017
The Energy and Resource Institute (TERI). 2013. Widening the coverage of PAT Scheme, Sectoral Manual – Vegetable oil industry, p. 15. Retrieved online from http://shaktifoundation.in/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/widening-of-pat-sectors-vegetable-refineries.pdf, last accessed 26/06/2017
